reviewText:
I'm only about 40 sausages in, and this is already one of the most beautifully designed puzzle games I've ever played. I've noticed that a lot of commenters in the discussion feel like the positive reviews aren't helpful, so instead of just getting all poetic about how awesome this game is, I'm going to try to be a little more concrete.

1. This is a game for puzzle-game lovers. If you're not into puzzle games, it isn't going to thrill you. If you love puzzle games, but aren't super into Sokoban-style games (like me), you are going to end up surprised by how much you love this. It's basically Sokoban-like, but it takes the concept to a whole new level. I will try to be specific:

a) The sausage fork is both a tool and a handicap. As a tool, it allows you to push sausages in directions other than straight ahead (and do other things I won't spoil). As a handicap, it constrains how you can situate yourself to push sausages.

b) A sausage itself has two sides, and each push (with exceptions I won't spoil) rolls it to the other side. This creates extra constraints when trying to grill each side only once. Sausages are also two tiles long, which creates extra constraints based on both orientation (vertical or horizontal) and grilling all four parts of the sausage.

These additions to the basic Sokoban-like mechanic result in a very large design space for difficult and epiphany-producing puzzles. Great puzzle games are about two things: constraints and topography. SSR hits a sweet-spot (or a spicy-spot if that's your preferred sauage type) for a simple system of rules that produces a wealth of complexity.

But a wealth of complexity doesn't automatically result in a great puzzle game. There also needs to be a great designer who mines that huge space of possibilities for the most devilish ideas and unintuitive twists. And this is what's getting SSR so much critical praise. The levels are designed for maximum epiphany and minimum repetition of tricks. It's a subtle kind of novelty, but every puzzle gives you something new.

2. Can you discover how awesome SSR is within the refund period? Possibly. If you do two or three puzzles on the second island and your mind isn't blown, though, it might just not be your thing. My particular mind was blown pretty early on. I found myself skipping puzzles and then solving them on a background thread as I was driving somewhere. That's a pretty sublime feeling. Another sublime feeling is the sense that a puzzle is simply impossible, follwed by the discovery of a solution. This has happened to me constantly while playing SSR.

3. The art style. I see people calling it simplistic" and "primitive"
date: which I think misunderstands it a little
recommended: because it implies that it's unintentional or the result of inability. My sense is that the game looks the way the person who made it wants it to look. Part of the fun of the game is the campiness. If it were logs or plain cylinders instead of sausages
hoursPlayed: it wouldn't be as endearing. And if the world and its sausages were rendered more realistically
voteText: I don't even know what I'd think. It would probably be creepy. Again
helpfulPercent: though -- if the art style isn't to your taste
votesHelpful: then it will probably detract from the enjoyment for you.\n\n4. The price. I write games myself
votesFunny: but I really like seeing indie games being priced higher than a crappy Domino's pizza. I don't know how many hours it will take me to finish the game
commentsCount: but I've seen people with over 30 hours in it who aren't done yet. A buck an hour doesn't seem like a lot to me
column16: when I often spend twice that rate for a 45-minute TV show. I can understand not wanting to spend that much
column17: but I don't really get why people feel offended by it. It's a market. The seller sets a price and people either buy it or don't. It ends up being either a good decision or a bad one
column18: and that's pretty much that.\n\nSummary: I love puzzle games as much or more than I love sausages
column19: and this is likely to be one of my favorite games of all times. We have entered the Golden Age of puzzle games
column21: so pony up the 22 quid and bask in its greasy

reviewText:
2 hours in so far and this game is fiendishly difficult! If you are not a fan of hardcore puzzle games this one may not be for you, and if you ARE fan you will adore this game. Much like The Witness (hard not to draw comparisons, but that's not a bad thing I suppose), there is a world to explore with puzzles to encounter out in the open. Each technique you learn helps you maneuveur the sausage and gives way to new methods of solving puzzles, which I can only assume will get EVEN MORE DIFFICULT.


+ Puzzle design is insanely clever, and cannot be brute forced.
+ Plays with expectations on with more obvious solutions being wrong, forcing you to think oustide the bun.
+ World map flows from puzzle to puzzle, feels much more involved than just having menus with puzzles to choose from.


- My biggest gripe so far is not being able to progress to the next set of puzzles until you solve EVERY one in an area. I foresee this being a brutal blocker if a puzzle is giving me a lot of trouble...
- The music is good, but a little too... experimental/serialist at times? It can be a little unsettling...

reviewText:
One of the best puzzle games I've ever played. Every level has a unique idea and there are a lot of them.
The puzzles are really difficult and there are many subtle ways to manipulate the sausages but the game does a good job to make sure you've mastered a set of techniques before introducing the next concept that blows your mind.

10/10

reviewText: Stephen's Sausage Roll is the latest puzzler from Stephen Lavelle (English Country Tune). It's ablock moving" game and a premium-priced indie. It's also flat-out amazing.\n\nIn SSR
date: you guide the player around an over-world with nodes representing discreet puzzles. When you land on one
recommended: the world drops away into a smaller puzzle area. There you're tasked with sliding and rolling raw sausages around the board in an attempt to grill both sides evenly via the strategically placed hot grill tiles embedded in the ground. Roll a cooked side of the sausage over the grill again and it's burned...game over. Roll it off the level and it's game over. The puzzles are ingenious. The puzzles are challenging. The puzzles are addictive.\n\nSSR sports a raw
voteText: morphing colors and an abstract soundtrack. It looks rough in stills
helpfulPercent: but is absolutely charming in motion. Controlling your character is strange
votesHelpful: as it doesn't adhere to traditional tank controls as you might imagine. Instead movement is absolutely relative to the direction your pointing in. There's a learning curve
votesTotal: but it comes together and makes sense when you start to understand the finesse needed to "thread the needle" around sausages and environmental obstacles.\n\nAs mentioned
votesFunny: the game is challenging as hell. Even from the start. One nice related feature is the ability to take back moves
commentsCount: one at a time with the Z key. Even after a level fail (rolling sausages into the water / burning sausages) you can execute this option
column16: alleviating frustration when you're stringing together moves to set up a level clear.\n\nI think SSR looks incredible. It absolutely nails the low-fi aesthetic. Nails it to the wall.  All you have to do is look at the Game Over screen to recognize this is all intentional.  Just look at that font! If someone didn't legitimately have the talent to pull off successful visual design
column17: there's no way they'd out themselves by choosing that font style. It takes confidence and deliberate intent to visually create something on the level of Stephen's Sausage Roll.\n\nReviews are saying there's a TON of content on offer here. 30+ hours of evolving mechanics that keep the game fresh with new ideas even late game. Still
column18: a $30 asking price for a game that looks like an itch.io project might be a bridge to far for many. Totally understandable. I opted in after reading some rave reviews coupled with the praise heaped on it from the puzzler dev community itself. Jonathan Blow (Braid / The Witness) described SSR as
column19: "one of the best puzzle games ever made
column20: or one of the best video games ever made”\n\nSo I held my breath and dropped $30 on the game. I'm REALLY glad I did as it's pressing all the right buttons for me. I went to bed thinking about game tactics and solutions. I woke up and got ready for my day thinking about tactics and solutions. And here I sit at work
column21: wishing I were at home executing tactics and solutions.\n\nKind of funny how the best and the brightest of the year can wind up being the games you never knew you wanted. Much like Stardew Valley
column22: I didn't know about Stephen's Sausage Roll until days before release. Yet I can quite comfortably see both placing on my end of year Top 10.\n"

reviewText:
If you're a fan of difficult puzzle games that let you take the initiative to explore the ruleset and ideas contained with in, I can't recommend Stephen's Sausage Roll enough.

Pros:
+Some of the best design I've seen in a game, both in terms of puzzles and overall structure.
+The introduction of new mechanics over time works extremely well, as soon as you feel like you've learned all you can learn about one idea, another one is introduced that surprises you with all its possibilities.
+The distinct lack of tutorials might seem off-putting for some, but the game is better for it, as it lets you know that it expects you to take initiative in figuring things out on your own.
+Many puzzles are very challenging, but never tedious. All of them have their own twists and turns on the core concept" of the area.
+Music is very ambient
date: which works well to not be obtrusive while working on puzzles.\n+There is a day/night cycle in the game which keeps more difficult levels from seeming like you've been staring at the same collection of blocks for hours on end.\n+Visual style is very helpful
recommended:
it lets you easily see at a glance how the level is laid out by tile count.

Cons:
-The content is finite.

Get this game and roll some sausages."

reviewText:
Conceptually, I like Stephen's Sausage Roll quite a bit. I think that the core gameplay mechanics are fun and interesting. The window dressing is fantastic- talking about rolling sausages and grilling them is worth a laugh by itself. The puzzles are simply sublimely designed and make use of every single bit of sausage-rolling complexity the game's ruleset has to offer.

All of this is a shame because the game is so relentless in its difficulty that it ruins the whole experience. The puzzles start at a pretty good level of challenge- you might not understand all of the rules and strategies quite yet, but the scope of each discrete puzzle is small enough that you quickly figure out strategies and work toward a solution. You'll eventually solve each of the puzzles in the first area and move onto the second, where the puzzles follow a similar formula and scope. All of this is fine until you reach The Great Tower- a Jenga-stacked tower of 8 sausages that represents the game's first difficulty wall. Suddenly, you can no longer solve a puzzle through simple trial and error- you need to develop a plan of experimentation and strategy of attack to even begin to understand the scope of the puzzle.

Provided you do in fact grill all of the sausages that compose The Great Tower, you will find that it isn't simply a one-off boss fight" of sorts- this is your new sausage grilling reality
date: as numerous puzzles in the next area follow its newfound scope. And that's basically where I draw the line! I like puzzle games
recommended: but the level of difficulty here moves from simple brain-teasers and logic exercises to full-fledged logistic projects in their complexity. It also feels that as the game goes on it loses a bit of its focus- instead of each puzzle tightly focusing on a mechanic
hoursPlayed: much of the later puzzles require long strings of execution and moves. It no longer gives you that "a-ha" moment without lengthy experimentation. It's simply too much work and effort for anybody but die-hards.\n\nUltimately- although I really do like the game's ideas
voteText: I really don't think that I could recommend it to anybody."

reviewText:
I just beat the game. I can't believe how much there was too this game. I didn't particularly enjoy the first area, but after that, just about every single puzzle for the next 30 hours of my playthrough was exceptional. Every time I thought there couldn't possibly be any more new ideas required to solve puzzles I was proven wrong. It's amazing how much content there is with the simple game mechanics of the player, a fork and sausages.

As a side note, Steam thinks I only have 11 hours or played, which is because I played on linux and the game crashed a lot when I ran through steam. When I ran the game outside of steam it never crashed, but also never accumulated my playtime. I definitely have over 40 hours of playtime now that I've finished the game.

My absolute favorite puzzle is Drumlin !

reviewText: A truly brilliant puzzle game. It takes the mechanics so much further than you would imagine, to the point there are genuinely Oh my god
date: did that just happen?" moments. I got 30 hours of thoroughly enjoyable play out of this and can see myself playing it again at some point
recommended:
so it was worth every penny. I have only positive points to make:

- Very challenging puzzles right from the get-go.
- There *is* a learning curve - a very well crafted one - it just starts you off high. I'd say the level of difficulty is consistent throughout (given that you are also learning as you go).
- There are a lot of puzzles.
- The puzzles are meticulously designed such that they all have very interesting
hoursPlayed:
completely different solutions and you can see how everything was arranged to make that solution and only that solution work.
- Pretty much every puzzle twists what you know about the mechanics (some will have you proclaiming "This is impossible!" before you *get* it).
- Every puzzle is super satisfying (to the point I'm shouting YESSSSS after each one).
- The graphics and audio are very well designed to not get in the way but also add a lot of character.
- Exploring the overworld is very enjoyable.
- You truly feel like you've improved as a puzzle solver by the end of it - there's a very definite evolution in the way you think about the puzzles.

There was almost a point early in the game (maybe 2-3 hours in) where I could have stopped playing
voteText: simply because I couldn't see where it was going. If you get past that hurdle
helpfulPercent: you'll be glad you did.\n\nPerfect for puzzle fans. Couldn't recommend it enough. Also recommend having a friend playing the game as well so you can talk about ideas and spur each other on. If you're not sure

reviewText: Stephen Sausage Roll exceeded my expectations, even though they were really high ones. This is a hard puzzle game, some levels are really really hard, but the game keeps pushing you to move away from your first thought, and experimenting, so I never really felt bored or stressed out on a level. reviewText:
I've finally grilled all the sausages. This is the best puzzle game. Every individual puzzle is just so damn clever, no two puzzles are alike, and there are SO many puzzles. If you enjoy puzzles, you will like this game.

The difficulty comes because no two puzzles are solved in the same way. The game's mechanics are the same from the start until the end, involving rolling sausages and walking around, but each puzzle puts you in a scenario where you have to use the same old mechanics in a novel way.

Usually, this is difficult because you didn't understand certain consequences of how the mechanics work. But once you flail around for a while and solve a puzzle, the consequences were clearly logical: how could you not have thought of that? Argh, it was right there.

This makes the puzzles feel straightforward and more importantly fair, even though solving them may be a struggle. There is no busywork of pushing around boring things that don't matter to the main idea of the puzzle. When you get an idea for how to solve a puzzle, it's quick to see whether it works. When you get the right idea, you KNOW it works, because the puzzles don't have unrelated filler and they're easy to think about. So the problem just becomes having the right idea, which is a LOT of fun if you like puzzles.

I don't think most people are going to complete the first area in the 2-hour refund time. I certainly didn't. That's a shame, because although the first area's puzzles are good for what they are, and are necessary to teach how the game works, they are probably the weakest part of the game. As you learn things about how the game works, the puzzles keep getting better and better until the end. It's an extremely impressive body of work.

There is also an engaging story, which was pretty surprising! It starts off extremely vague, but later in the game there's more story text between every one or two puzzles. Getting more of the story was a good motivation for solving some more puzzles.

I really liked this game. And I'm definitely going to get some replay value out of it: I've already forgotten how most of the puzzles work!

reviewText:
Stephen' Sauasage Roll is a possibly one of the best thought out puzzle games I've ever played. Unlike other Sokoban-like puzzle games, I feel like I could solve almost every puzzle I've played so far a second time without having too much trouble, and every puzzle has felt different. The puzzles in this game are about understanding what your options are, and they all feel much more open than other box pushing games. This means that you can't brute force a solution, but it also means that you're more open to experiment with the mechanics (which you'll have to do a lot). After every puzzle I felt like I understood the game better for having solved it, even if only a little bit. I encourage anyone who likes puzzle games, or even those who just enjoy thinking, to try this game.

EDIT: I just beat the game and I feel like I should add a few things, although I promise to keep it spoiler free. Firstly, The ending to the game is very poetic and almost entirely satisfying. To explain it any further would be a disservice to Stephen's work, so you'll just have to see it for yourself. I can say, however, that it was a perfect way to end the game.

Secondly, the amount of thought and planning that must've gone into this game as a whole more than justifies the asking price, and if you count the time I spent think about the puzzles outside of playing the game it come out to about 2 days worth of play" time. Although I may have gotten stumped a few times I always managed to find a solution with relative ease the next day
date: usually by considering an entirely different angle to approach the problem from.\n\nAlso
recommended: the slow reveal of new mechanics was paced perfectly. One in particular Was so unexpected and mind blowing that I had to undo my moves and watch it happen a second time just to comprehend what had happened. I you thought this game was simple then you are sorely mistaken.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: I have to say that this game is easily the best puzzle game I've ever played in my entire life. I've heard this called the Dark Souls of puzzle games
voteText: but I think it'd be more accurate to call it the Citizen Kane of puzzle games instead.\n\nStephen Lavelle
helpfulPercent: you are truly a master fo your craft!"
commentsCount: 13 of 21 people (62%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's a series of puzzle games out there which need no description. They are all designed to explore specific interactions in the puzzle rule set, and are purely puzzle games (no relevant story). Such games include Antichamber, The Witness, English Country Tune, SnakeBird and of course, Stephen's Sausage Roll, the newest brilliant adition to the group. (plus many others).

It's more relevant to decide if this game is for YOU than talk about the game.

- if you enjoyed any of the other games on the list, or like very difficult puzzle games, grab this!
- If you're new to puzzle games or you're not looking for a purely hardcore puzzle experience, grab something like Portal. Stephen's Sausage Roll may seem unfair. That's not due to the difficulty, but the music, visuals and lack of instructions (other than what the keys do) make it a bit hard to digest in some scenarios.

Despite all this, there's been a torrent of sausage jokes around here, and I honestly can't remeber when's the last time I thought so hard about wieners...

reviewText: This is a brilliant puzzle game. It's similar to Snakebird in that it has intentionally simple graphics and focuses the gameplay on the puzzles. Stephen's Sausage Roll goes beyond Snakebird by having more puzzles, a wider variety of puzzle mechanics, and pushing those mechanics to their limits.

reviewText: Stephen's Sausage Roll is a puzzle game by Increpare. In any of the puzzles, there is not a single thing to distract you from getting to the solution, not necessary the solution, but the knowledge you achieve after solving a puzzle. Every little detail is put in place with great care and has a purpose to it, so much so that you can complete your idea of a solution through finding out what those details mean and where they would play a roll. Many of the levels seem pretty hard or even impossible at first, but the game let's you trust it -- it wouldn't be there, if it were impossible. No new mechanic is added throughout the game, yet the game constantly surprises you with its already rich mechanics, every aspect of which plays some roll somewhere in this game. It drives you to a state where you are forced to doubt everything you trusted, and consider everything you ruled out. There is no hand-holding, the game is filled with as much precious content as possible, every level needs not only one but several moments of epiphany, some of which wouldn't even be needed in that particular level, but are a natural result of the interaction between your mind and the level. It takes your mind so deep in the universe of ideas and possibilities that you forget the simplest of actions once you have the solution. Stephen's Sausage Roll is probably the best puzzle game ever made and it's a treasure full of awe. It doesn't try to deceive you through fancy narrative and graphics, or easy-to-solve levels. It doesn't waste your time, there is no secret mechanic, no secret key or hidden object; everything you need is in front of you. It's as honest and true as a game can be.

reviewText:
I'm still early in the game but I've already played a few puzzles that made this game worth every cent, they were so mindblowingly brilliant.

I'm not great at puzzle games by any means, but I think this game does a great job of easing you into its way of thinking, and combined with its relatively limited set of actions (at least at first), it feels way different to me than what I would consider straight up just brutal puzzle games.

Put it this way: each puzzle contributes its own small chunk of understanding how the mechanics of the game work, bit by bit, while still offering a notable challenge every time. I can get how many would be put off by the first few puzzles, but after that initial hurdle (maybe solving some of the 1 sausage puzzles first) you start to gain some confidence and then are on your way to being a sausage grilling champ.

All the above plus the super charming presentation, and this is already a game I'd recommend to anyone who enjoys puzzles or brain teasers.

reviewText:
This game melted my brain, and then made me eat too many sausages. I am now an obese mess. 10/10, would overconsume delicious sausages again

siriusly tho, this game is HARD. And it pretty much just dumps you in the deep end with no instructions or guidance, and lets you figure it out for yourself. There are easy levels on the first island, though they're not necessarily the first one's you'll be drawn to. If you aren't getting anywhere on a puzzle at first, drop it and go to another while you figure out how the game works.
The game itself is a fun variation on the sokoban/block pushing type puzzles. Except you're rolling/grilling sausages, instead of lining up blocks to get past.

It will make you hungry. Hungry for delicious sausage. You have been warned.

reviewText:
So far, this nightmare has consumed 11.3 hours of my time, and produced 132 delicious, perfectly-cooked sausages.

This is the most difficult, aggravating, satisfying, and beautiful puzzle game I've ever played. Fans of sokoban-style transport puzzles will eat this up.

I'm glad grilling sausages IRL isn't this frustrating, but sad that grilling sausages IRL doesn't result in the same sense of triumph.

reviewText: Amazing, beautfully designed, and unbelievably difficult puzzle game. All without ever being repetitive or unfair. If you like the idea of exploring, discovering and applying every possible interaction between a deceptively small number of puzzle pieces, this is the game for you. Provided you don't cheat, this game will last you quite a while, as more than a few of the puzzles require you to put them aside and sleep on them. There's always an answer there when you look hard enough, and plenty of amazing Aha!" moments. Get ready to put your life on hold and become one with the sausages."

I also like how the game lets you play past the point of failure and discover new level and sausage rolling mechanics through trial and error.\n\nI looked up the solution to one puzzle and I regretted it.

reviewText:
Disclosure: I got a free copy of this game for beta testing, and am online friends with the developer (we're both indie game developers). I also didn't yet finish the game, but played a few hours and got through the first set of puzzles.

This is a game that gives fairly little explanation, seems to intentionally avoid having a tutorial, and has some really clever puzzles. The puzzles start out very hard and get harder. When you first play, you probably won't be able to solve a single one, and most of them will seem like there isn't any possible way that they could be solved. But when you solve one, the pleasure of finally figuring it out will be so great that all the frustration will be worth it.

I understand that there is a lot of trepidation due to the relatively high price. If someone is worried about that, just google 'increpare'. The developer has created and released over 100 games for free, most short and experimental. If someone isn't sure that they want to spend so much money on what is a leap of faith, they could play those first (or exclusively). I particularly recommend his free game Opera Omnia"."

reviewText:
Sooooo hungry. Do not play this game unless you like really hard puzzles based on very simple mechanics, and you have a plentiful supply of real sausages to beat the hunger pangs that will result from rolling delicious virtual sausages back and forth.

It's supposed to have full controller support, but on Linux I needed a custom config for the Steam controller to do anything. Once that's set up it works very nicely.

Also British people should be aware that this game is about rolling sausages, not about sausage rolls, the delicious snack made from a sausage wrapped in puff pastry. As far as I know you never get to wrap your sausages in pastry. It's still a good game though.

I haven't got very far yet, but have already had ups and downs. It starts hard, but after a while I made some breakthroughs and was able to race through the next few puzzles. But then I hit another wall and got stuck again.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Last night I dreamed of The Great Tower. In it a million timelines crowded onto a singular pasture. Phantoms selves laboured endlessly with somnanbulistic intensity. Their eyes blank as spider's eggs, sausages scabbed and leathery. Like a turtle's nest boiling over onto a beach, the realities superimposed upon each other hideously. And in this vertiginous tower of babel there lay no solution, merely a mute resignation to the eternal return of my failure.

This morning I have woken to a reality I can no longer believe in. This task will be my tombstone.
Soon The Great Tower will be my world.

reviewText: I'm not finished with the game yet, or even close. Will update upon finishing it. Seems people are reporting an average of 35 to even 60 hour play times if that is of interest though.\n\nSo far it's great, I absolutely love it. As many people have already said, the design is where it shines. The game never tells you what or how to do anything. You begin pushing and rolling sausages to fully cook them around and while it seems like a simple premise, you are constantly learning new things and playing the game in a much different way than you were before so it never feels repetitive. Often I get stuck and then realize, Oh wow I can do that?" While being designed in a way where I naturally stumbled upon it by trying things that seemed possible. I have never thought
date: "Oh how was I suppose to think of that?" You can undo every move you make too so trying new things is encouraged.\n\nBut don't be fooled by its funny name or silly premise. This is one of the hardest puzzle games out there. Think of something like Snakebird
recommended:
another extremely hard game that looks all cute and innocent on the outside. So don't complain when you get stuck within the first 10 minutes of the game. (Of course I also still have much left to do so it's just going to get even more difficult. Though I look forward to it).

I can see why Jonathan Blow (Braid/The Witness) has cited this game as one of the greatest puzzle games of all time. Alexander Bruce (Antichamber) has given the game high praise as well.

The developer Increpare has created English Country Tune and a multitude of other small little games. Games I would also recommend checking out. He's mostly known among devs and people who actually watch out for these lesser known titles. But I hope that changes
hoursPlayed: I hope more and more outlets begin to review/cover this game.\n\nStephen's Sausage Roll deserves it."

reviewText:
Bought and finished Starseed Pilgram on Jonathan Blow's word.  Completed it.  Was not disappointed.

Bought this on Jonathan's word.  Am not disappointed.  If one compares to classic Sokoban (which this game, at some level, could be called a derivative work or, at least, in the same general genre), one would see many innovative game ideas.

And then one gets to the second area where <spoiler eludied> elements are introduced.  The game is now in a newly defined genre of puzzle games.  Mind blowing.

New comment after 30+ hours of play:
And then one gets to the fifth area of the game and one wonders how they ever compared this game to Sokoban.

Puzzle game of the Year 2016.

reviewText: Beautifully elegent design and some of the hardest puzzles you will ever encounter in a game.  Your progress will be slow and it takes some time to learn and get used to the movement but before long you'll be in the swing of things and each puzzle will leave you feeling like a genius.  If you're a puzzle game lover, especially stuff like The Witness where you figure everything out yourself, then you will love this.  And yes, considering how much fun I've had and how much content this game has, it is absolutely worth the price.

reviewText:
Really interesting puzzle game.  Does an astounding amount with each mechanic.  Really keeps you thinking!

Despite the positive review, to be totally honest, I returned it after half an hour.  I'm quite interested in where it's going, but I'm not sure this deep level of difficulty is going to keep me engaged for long enough to justify $30.  Despite that, I'll definitely be picking it up again when it's cheaper- I just don't know how long I'll be gripped.

People who like mentally challenging puzzle games, definitely check this out!  If you liked Snakebird or The Witness, it's a good purchase.  Otherwise, maybe hold off for a bit,  but still keep an eye on it.  It's an interesting enough experience that you'll probably want to get it at some point.

It's a solid puzzler though. Would reccomend.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Disclosure: review copy received from the developer.

Good lord, this is both like and not like Snakebird. If you enjoyed the puzzles in Snakebird, you'll probably like this; if you didn't, you don't want this one. They're similar in that both games require you to really think about every single move you make; positioning is key, and movement is weird. I don't expect to be good enough to finish it.

Given its steep price, I wouldn't recommend it to any but the most hardcore of puzzle game lovers.

P.S. I love the way puzzle selection works -- you must either stumble onto one via luck or master the basics of movement just to start puzzles.

recommended:
its core virtues are in its mechanics and in its level design. The second difficulty is that discovering the mechanics is an integral part of the game so keeping things spoiler free without being vague is tough. Let's try though.


The incredible elegance of Stephen's Sausage Roll comes from the fact that from the very start of the game to its very end all the rules of the world are there

reviewText:
I was fortunate enough to become a tester for this gem of a game. Stephen's Sausage Roll is one of the most carefully designed games I've had the pleasure of playing. It's also one of the most challenging puzzle games I've ever played.

You begin shipwrecked on a mysterious island. Your only tool is a strange fork and all you can do is move forward, backward, and rotate. You're given very little information, but you'll soon find yourself in one of the game's devious puzzles. Your goal? To roll sausages over to the grill tiles placed on the floor and cook them. That's it. SSR forgoes complex mechanics seen in other puzzle games for simplicity and elegance. You may not see how you can use your limited moveset to accomplish what you want, but there is always a way.

Aesthetically, Stephen's Sausage Roll is a succulent treat. Colorful low-fi visuals, soothing accompaniment, a day and night cycle, and an overall tranquil atmosphere. There's also some cryptic story to be uncovered in notes you'll find throughout the island.

Now, as I said before, this game is hard. The puzzle-solving is based on experimentation and your familiarity with the (sometimes hidden) mechanics. Luckily the game is very forgiving in this regard. You're given access to a variety of puzzles at the start of each area and you have unlimited undos available for when you mess up (and this will happen). SSR expects you to learn from its challenges and it's very adept at teaching you new things through the puzzle solutions you discover (sort of like The Witness).

Overall, this game is really something special for puzzle game fans. I admit I haven't made it that far in the game, even with all my hours of play, but I'm excited to see what awaits. Sausage is tasty and so is this game.

reviewText:
Only get this game if you are A) extremely good with puzzles or B) don't value your sanity.

second warning: If you're anything like me then you will become obsessed with this game so don't get it if you have any urgent work that needs doing; It is utterly consuming for anyone who likes puzzles/math problems and/or strange worlds with a sense of mystery.

the first bit wasn't surprising much, though it was for the purpose of exposition and it was solid, but the second part made me much more intrigued right away. One of the puzzles in that part is particularly interesting/satisfying compared to the other ones, and already distinguishes this from almost all games i've played.

the third part feels much more at the core at what it seems to want to achieve, mostly having solutions that revolve around one key moment of understanding.

now having completed the fourth and fifth parts, i'm getting to the REALLY good stuff in the sixth part.

I think I've spent far too much time being stuck on things only to realize the solution was simpler than i thought, but it seems worth going through and finding out how things work.


AFTER HAVING COMPLETED THE GAME:::

A very unique experience. Left with a feeling there possibly could've been more, but maybe that was only because I had very high expectations, and probably everything in it was all that is needed. I maybe might've ruined it for myself by getting hints on two things, but overall, the last part of the game and the time after gives me a cloud of a strange feeling, somewhat inspiration, somewhat remorse.

Basically for anyone who likes their games to be very meaty.




MMMM SAUSAGE
MMMMMMMM

reviewText: (Disclosure: I'm in the credits as a tester) One of the best games ever made. Unlike basically every other puzzle game, it asks you to solve a new deep problem on every single level. There's very little emphasis on forward planning, and puzzles are compact but impossible to brute-force. It starts as a soko-ban-like game, but quickly unfolds into something much more ambitious. It's incredibly tough but never in an unfair or arbitrary way, and by the end of the game (40-80 hours I would say) you feel an incredible sense of expertise.\n

reviewText:
Just played the first few levels, so take this with a huge grain of salt as I literally just started it. I also made a video to show off the gameplay, which you can see here: https://youtu.be/KbWNYiWCzn4

The controls take a lot to get used to and feel very cumbersome at first, which isnt a good sign for a puzzle game. However, the difficulty in controls were very well integrated into the (excellent) level design and game mechanics, creating some extremely devious challenges. If you want to sink your teeth into a puzzle game, this will give you a lot more meat than you can chew.

Word of caution though, the base mechanic does revolve around pushing blocks" (or sausages in this case) and its not too far off from other similar games like Sokoban. Stephen's sausage roll is adding another level of complexity onto a very familiar subgrenre (block pushing puzzle games)
recommended:
but it is also not really pushing for anything new. And the price point is sort of the sore thumb here in regards to that. From what I can see so far:

Is it a good game? Yes.
Does it deserve your money? Absolutely.
Is it worth 30$? That is entirely up to you
hoursPlayed: in regards of how much you value challenge in your puzzle games.\n\nI love challenging puzzle games and I am looking forward to biting into this eventually when I have more time for it
voteText: but I appreciate new ideas more than I do just challenges

reviewText: One of the most challenging puzzle games out there, but never unfairly so. The mechanic of just pushing, rolling, and navigating the sausage to its grill is intuitive, and surprisingly deep. Recommended!\nPlus, it has sausages, which, as a German, I love very much.

reviewText: Challenging game! So satisfying when you get your head around it. Loved grappling with all those sausages. I could listen to that title screen music all day too.

reviewText: You have to play the game to understand it and solving each puzzle is really satisfying. Even the puzzle selection screen is kind of a puzzle. I like it. :-)
voteText: 14 of 63 people (22%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game, huh? What a package!

Right from the word go this game had me in love with it. The opening menu makes me warm and fuzzy each and every time I load it. I sit there and smile, whilst it plays out. Then there's the overworld music. It reminds me of Firelink Shrine in Dark Souls. It's eery, yet safe.

The gameplay and puzzles are fantastic and will have you pulling your hair out, consuming you when you can't play it, begging you to go back as soon as you can because you think you know the answer.

SSR is like the Dark Souls of puzzle games. It doesn't explain anything to you, it doesn't hold your hand but let's you just go about your thing. Lastly, it gives you a good, old fashioned challenge, which until recently with games like Snakebird and The Witness, were pretty rare.

I'm super impressed and highly recommend SSR. Now go roll some sausages!
voteText: 10 of 58 people (17%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: I bet you are wondering what this game is actually like to play and whether it's worth your money. After all the reviews are deliberately cryptic. The artwork looks cheap. It has a gimmick title. You are probably weary of the joke comments and bad punning. To you people I say this: SAUSAGES.

reviewText: Cook sausages evenly in tight quarters with a forklift. With the help of a rewind feature and an open world reminiscent of The Witness, what would be a clunky and obtuse sokoban puzzler feels more like a relaxing toy that rewards experimentation and exploration.\n\nIt's almost enough to make me want to see how the sausage is made!

reviewText: If you like these types of puzzle games, know that this is likely one of the greatest, and well worth the price. (Heck, you don't want to know what The Adventures of Lolo on the NES originally cost, adjusted for inflation.  This is easily better.  :P )
